instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00239: What is 820-00239? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <RESISTOR>R7075</RESISTOR> still shorting to the ground after replacing it.
threads.message:
The <RESISTOR>R7075</RESISTOR> was 67ohm which should be 4.7ohms ,with alcohol heat test show the <RESISTOR>R7075</RESISTOR> is boiling , i replaced <RESISTOR>R7075</RESISTOR> from the same donor board which i get now 5.1ohms which sound about right .
but this <RESISTOR>R7075</RESISTOR> still  boiling with the same test , PPDCIN only 5.2 <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> 0 volt . <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 0 volt . 
when check short to ground this Resistor still shorting . do i need to replace <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> ?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <RESISTOR>R7075</RESISTOR> still shorting to the ground after replacing it.
threads.message:
Short on <SIGNAL>TBA_VDDA</SIGNAL>.
Check <CAPACITOR>C7075</CAPACITOR> first, but pretty sure to be <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>.

Always check for short before power up a board.
No need voltage to find a short.
Now you must change <RESISTOR>R7075</RESISTOR> again...
